South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.
PALESTINE - SYRIA LINE.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).
RED SEA LINE.

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.

div.head: NATIVE PRESS IN EGYPT.
div.p: A correspondent of the Morning Post" sends an interesting letter dealing with the danger of indiscreet discussions of Egyptian affairs in the House of Commons, and the encouragement given thereby to the writers in the native Press, with its consequent evil results. Freedom of speech in Parliament is, he says, one of the bulwarks of oar Constitution; but, that there are occasions when the abuse of this privilege can do an irreparable amount of harm has been only too clearly proved during the last few weeks in the case of the Egyptian outrage. Some British officers were the victims of a brutal assault, said to be due to increasing fanaticism among the natives. The Egyptian Government with great promptitude assembled a Court composed of men who had had long experience of the country and the law, and in whose judgment everyone had the utmost confidence. This Court meted out to the guilty persons well-deserved punishments, which it was confidently hoped would have a most salutary effect upon a large district notorious for the criminal instincts of its popalation. There is little doubt that these hopes would have been realised if the matter had been allowed to rest at this point. But soch, unfortunately, was not the case. Ingamerable questions were asked in the House of Commons with a view to eliciting some fact which would throw blame on the British officer, and to afford an excuse for the murderers. What is the result 1 These questions in the English House of Parliament are at once taken by the native Press to mean that there is a large amount of sympathy in England for the convicted men. Inflammatory articles fill the papers until the reader is led to believe that the judgment of the Court has been strongly condemned in England.

The native Press professes to represent the Nationalist Party in Egypt, and it is impossible. to know what proportion of the people are in -sympathy with it. But it is certain that these papers are sold in enormous quantities and find their way into almost every house-if not the paper itself, at all events the contents. These papers, which number under tea, are of a very low order, and contain chiefly vicious attacks on the British, and by gross exaggeration and misrepresentation of facts try to stir up a hostile feeling among the lower classes. Even if their opinions are not at the present time those held by the majority of the people, the native papers, spread broadcast over the towns, are bound to do an enormous amount of mischief, particularly at the present time, when fanaticism is believed to be on the increase. One of the traits of the Egyptian character is that he will believe almost anything, no matter how absurd or palpably false, provided that it comes from the right source. One of these sources is the native Press.

The effects, then, of these articles appearing day after day are many and far-reaching. The native is led to believe that the punishments inflicted at Danishwai have been pronounced as unjustifiable in England, and' in the event of a like occurrence the miscreants would not be allowed to suffer such severe penalty. Again, British justice, which has always been. considered beyond question, is here believed to have miscarried, involving a loss of prestige at a time when we can least afford to lose it. All this, together with the spread of fanaticism, makes the presence of the Englishmen more and more intolerable to the Egyptians, who have become very anxious to be rid of a Christian influence in their country, which has become so obnoxious to them.

It seems a great pity, therefore, that steps are not taken to check the circulation of this class of literature. No one can seriously believe that the liberty of the Press would be endangered by the suppression of, or at any rate the application of a strict censorship to, these inflammatory sedition-mongering productions. At first, of course, there would be great outery, and opinions suppressed in the papers would probably find an outlet else where. But the people would not have them thrust before their eyes day after day in large type, and for those who cannot read in the form of cartoons which would be grotesque if they were not so dangerous. And those who look to the Press to provide them with opinions would either have none or go to some less powerful source for them. It is, indeed, a matter of the greatest importance, Nand one which in the end must be dealt with by the authorities if the present tide of feeling is to be stemmed, and the longer it is delayed the more difficult it will be. It is to be hoped, therefore, that something may be done before long to put a stop once for all Ito this great evil, which is gradually untiemining our interests and thereby endangering the prosperity of this country.
The Brindisi Mail.
The mail for Europe, vilal Port Said and Brindisi, wil close at the G.P.O., Alexandria, at 3.10 pm on Monday.
Coal Importi
The imports of coal from January 1 to 9th inst amounted to 703,431 tons, as compared to 569,868 tons during the same period last
year.
A Water Fantine.
Advices from Tripoli in Africa report a dearth of water among the tribes of Hamamra, near to Mislata, owing to the failure of forty wells which supplied the caravans.
Zagazig Telegraph Office.
Zagazig is to have a large telegraph office, and the Administration of Telegrapha has applied to the Ministry of Finance relative to the purchase of the necessary ground.
A Free Pharmacy.
The Alexandrian Masonic lodge, "Al Ma rouah," has decided to open a pharmacy where drag will be given and prescriptions made up to indigent application for assistance. Free State lands.

The Government Administrations have been notified by a circular of the Ministry of Finance that they must pay for all l'ree State lands that they may take over for their service, and that the price therefore must be included in their general expenditure.
Russian Refugees Fate.

This evening fête and a theatrical per- formance will be given at the French Garden, Alexandria, in aid of the Russian Jewish refugees. There will be a tombola and plenty of other amusements. The fête begins at 9.15 p.m. The "ota" not disposed of at Sunday's fete will utilised for a lottery.
Fatal Train Accident.

Several stive workmen were engaged in loading a goods train at Mallaba station yesterday, when another train. something from Al- Farg, collided with the standing wagons, some of which fell on the workmen One was killed, and four were seriously injured and had to be taken to hospital.
The Plague.

Yesterday's plague bulletin recorded a fresh case at Alexandria, the patient being a native boy living in the Menayar quarter. Today's bulletin records a case at Alexandria, of a young girl in the Karmous quarter, two cases (one fatal) at Suez, and two cases of Europeans 14 Port Said.
Burglary by Chaffins.

Our Keneh Correspondent reports a case of burglary by ghaffirs in Kensh bandar, in a house where occupants were absent. There were three of them, and they were disturbed in their nefarious occupation by the cries of a servant next door. They immediately took to flight, bat wire caught by the police patrol. Alhambra Theatre.

This evening Domas's well-known comedy Denise will be presented by the Novelli company. Tomorrow, there will be two performances, Guerra in Tempo di Pace in the after- noon and Disonesti, followed by Il Deputato di Bombigute, in the evening. Owing to the length of the programme the arts in will rise at 9.15 p.m. punctually.
Al Hayat.

The Al Hayat Hotel Company of Heliopan has purchased the San Giovanni estate, situated at the end of the Nile road, on the river. The old building has been demolished and a new tea-house has been erected on the site, which will afford a charming excursion to the numerous visitors to Halonan. The view of the Nile is exceptionally beneficial at this point, with all the pyramids of Dashour and Sakkara in the background and the palm forest of Bedreslin immediately on the other side of the river
Serious Carriage Accident.

Yesterday, a regrettable accident occurred in the Attain quarter of Alexandria whereby an Italian child of about twelve years of age was grievously hurt. A private carriage going at a rapid jace down one of the narrow lanes off the main Attarin 'reet runs over the child. He had his ye nearly torn int and suffered such serious contusions about the head and body that it is possible that his injuries will prove fatal. The driver of the carriage, en seeing the accident, whipped up his horses, and drove away at a rapid ate. As the carriage was a private one there are no means of identifying it. This is not the first time of late that such a system of escape has been, employed by coachmen of private carriages at Alexandria. A driver has been arrested on suspicion, whom the spectators of the accident believed to be guilty.
New Employment Registry.

The British Chamber of Commerce gives notice that it has commenced an employment register, which may be consulted by members requiring clerical or other assistance. Applications will be received, free of charge, from clerks and others wishing to obtain posts in Egypt. Address, Secretary, British Chamber of Commerce Alexandria. [Advt.]

div.head: THE SULTAN'S HEALTH.
DISQUIETING REPORTS.
div.p: A Reuter's telegram to-day states that there are renewed, well accredited reports that the Sultan is ill.

According to private advisors received in Cairo from Constantinople, the Sultan's health is giving cause for great anxiety, owing to his Majesty's refusal to undergo a surgical operation recommended by Dr. Bergmann of Berlin. The only nourishment the Sultan can support normally is milk, and as his Majesty takes too small a quantity to sustain him, the doctors had to have recourse to artificial means of feeding.

div.head: MUSTAPHA PASHA KAMEL.
div.p: A native newspaper, "Al Zaher," states that Mustapha Pasha Kemel received a subvention for carrying on his Denishwai campaign in London, and "Al Lewa," in its last issue, is at pains to exculpate its absent editor from the charge thos brought against him. The paper says that, on his departure for Europe, the Pasha took a cheque for 10,000 francs payable on the Crédit Lyonnais in Paris and, on the 2nd inst., the office of "Al Lewa" forwarded him another cheque for 5,000 francs on the same bank. The total, amounting to 15,000 francs, says our contemporary, refutes the false charges of "Al Zaher." We, however, fail to see the argument; at the same time, we may point out that "Al Zaher's" allegations equally fail to admit of proof.
The following letter appears in the "Standard" in reply to the letter which we reproduced in our columns on the 1st inst. :-
Monsieur le Directeur,- J'ai lu dans votre estimable journal la lettre du prétendu "Ami du peuple égyptien." Permettez moi de lui dire:-

1o. Que les lois égyptiennes sont très sévères pour les fomenteurs des troubles et que si nos journaux avaient excité les musulmans contre les chrétiens, Lord Cromer n'aurait pas laissé une si belle occasion pour traduire leurs rédacteurs devant les tribunaux.

2o. Que nous pouvions mettre nos journaux soas des protections étrangères, protégées par les capitulations, et échapper ainsi aux lois égyptiennes, mais nous avons accepté la responsabilité de nos écrits devant la loi, parce que nous sommes les premiers à désavouer les désordres et le trouble.
3. Nos journaux ne sont las que par l'élite, étant donné que le peuple be sait ni lire ni écrire.

4. Nous avons toujours conseillé à nos co-religionnaires la calme le plus absolu, et nous avons souvent en à lutter contre les intrignants qui attaquent l'Islam et ses chefs pour irriter la nation et l'exciter aux excès.
Quant à la bagarre de 10 Décembre dernier, le juge qui à étudié et jugé l'affaire a officiellement déclaré qu'il n'y avait point de fanatisme, et Lord Cromer a reconnu cette vérité dans son rapport.

Il est plus digne et aussi plus utile-de cesser ces calomnies contre la presse musulmane et de chercher à donner à l'Egypte une administration et une justice solides et capables d'assurer la tranquillité dans le pays. Veuillez agréer mes plus profonds respects.

div.head: SAMOS.
div.p: H.E. Costaki Caratheodory Effendi, the new Prince of Samos, arrived at Stamboul on the 2nd inst., and was received in audience by p H.I.M. the Sultan.
H.E Yanko Effendi Bithyaos, whom he suc ceeds in the Beylik, arrived from Samos the same day.

The new Bay of Samos, who leaves, almost 1 immediately for Vathy, is the younger brother of the late Alexander Caratheodory Pasha, O first translator of the Saltan, who died on the 26th January of this year.

Costaki Effendi is, amongst other qualifications, an excellent engineer, and it is to be hoped that he will make good use of his talents 1 towards the economical development of the Aegean Isle over which has been called to w rale. This election is a triumph for the h Sonfouli party, the leader of which was lately o in Constantinople and in company of M. o Gangos, agent for Samos, called on the Ecuminical Patriarch, when we suppose arrangements were made for securing the approval of Yildiz of the Patriarchal candidate.

div.head: EGYPTIAN COTTON IN SIND.
div.p: In a recent issue we gave a short account of the successful result of experiments with Egyptian cotton on the perennially irrigated lands of Sind, where immense sterile tracts are being rendered fertile by the extended utilization of canals. From this source a supply is anticipated within a few years of at least 100,000 bales of this high- grade cotton. It must be yet some years, before the full effect of the efforts that are being made will be attained, but there is little doubt that in time will come to the great advantage of the Indian cultivators such im- provement of Indian cotton as will provide Lancashire with a certain additional source of supply of the staples suited to its needs,

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Ellerman S.S. Falernian arrived at Liverpool yesterday morning.

div.head: COLD STORAGE.
div.p: MUNICIPAL REGULATIONS.

The Egyptian Government have not as yet ratified the regulations, drafted by the Alexandria Municipality, for the introduction of frozen meat into the city. The delay is due to the fact that there is some doubt as to whether the Municipality is not acting ultra vires in t imposing a tax of three millièmes per kilo for d the veterinary inspection of the meat that arrives here. Seeing the disclosures of the recent revelations on the Chicago packing trade, we are of the opinion that it is not three 1 that should be charged but a least thirty mille lièmes. The meat arriving in a frozen condition,it is impossible, without elaborate investigation, to discover what deleterious microbes he may be contained therein. Therefore, it will entail a very onerous duty on the veterinary D service of the Municipality to discover these microbes. In Port Said a flourishing business is being done in the frozen meat trade on account of the number of steamers passing through. In Alexandria, however, there is I little likelihood of the trade developing to any great extent owing to the fact that a very large proportion of the population is Moslem and Jewish, and religious prohibitions prevent them from consuming animals unless slaughtered in certain specified fashions.
ALEXANDRIA'S NEW HOTEL

The construction of the Savoy Palace Hotel is making rapid progress, and it is expected that this fire hotel will be open in November next. Mr. Rudolph Springer, the managing director of Al Hayat at Helouan, has been appointed managing director of the company, and Mr. Adolphe Auber, from Geneva, has been selected to manage the hotel. The hotel will have the largest dining room in Alexandria, capable of accommodating 200 guests. It is now being built facing north in Mariette Pasha street. By the dining room there will be a winter garden, twenty four by fifteen meters. It will be all roofed in with an iron and coloured glass roof, and will be warm in winter and bool in summer. There will be an English billiard-room, library, electric lift, and all the usual concomitants of a first-class hotel. There will be 150 rooms with a large number of private suites with bathrooms. On Rosetta Gate-street there will be a large Anglo American bar and saloon facing the street. The restaurant and the table d'hôte will be open to non-residents. A Tzigane orchestra will be permanently in attendance, and after- noon tea will be served. The manager has informed us that there will be specially reduced terms for officers of the Army of Occupation and officials of the Egyptian Government.

div.head: THE ATTARIN CRIME.
div.p: The general tenour of the comments of the local Press on the subject of the recent murder of Dr. Vavaropoulos is to the effect that the murder is to be extennated on the ground that the doctor was under a kind of moral and professional obligation to obey Pierini's request. This standpoint is combated by the medical profession. It is alleged that a doctor is perfect- ly justified in refusing to attend à patient, whom he does not know, unless he has received a fee beforehand. Certainly the lawyers are very careful before they take up an unknown client's case, and there is no reason why medical men should act differently.

div.head: PRISON BUILDING.
div.p: According to the report of the director of prison building the total sum expended during the past year in building was L.E. 57,851, almost half that amount being spent on the Keneh and Assiout new central prisons. Keneh prison was commenced on 1st May, 1904, and finished on 15th June, 1905. It contains one block only with a hospital, offices, laundry and workshop as well as a gate house and a house for the director over. execution room has also been built. The total cost of this prison was L.E. 21,366.

Assiout prison was commenced on 1st May, 1904, and finished on 10th October, 1905. This prison has two blocks with hospital, laundry, workshop, execution room, etc, and a gate house giving accommodation for the director over. It has also a women's prison consisting of a block and laundry and offices, with hospi- tal, etc. The total cost was L.E. 37,455. Several important additions have been made zat Menehieh prison. A large women's laundry has been built, which is quite self contained, having its own steam generating plant and steam ironing machine, etc. Two wings were added to the hospital buildings, giving on one side a new clothes' store, and an additional hospital ward for men over. A new system of drainage has been arranged and a sewage farm started at a distance of one kilometre and a half from Zagazig prison. The sewage is now pumped through a line of pipes to do this farm. A new first class prison was commenced at Delta Barrage on the 31st May, 8 1905, and is well in hand. A new reformatory for 500 boys and 100 girls at Ghizeh was commenced on the 24th June, 1905. The work is progressing well and during the pre- 8 rent year a large amount of building will be done. L.B. 5,857 was spent last year at this

div.head: MORALITY CRUSADE
THE SALVATION OF ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: The Alexandria City Police and the' consular authorities have decided to convene a meeting next November in order to discuss what measures should be taken to stamp out the demimondaine population of Alexandria, or at any rate restrict this class of the population to a certain quarter of the town. Bg

A member of the police of the Morality the Department of the Alexandria Convernorat was recently whipped by a British subject. The latter was in a cab at 3 a.m. with two ladies (1), one of whom sat on the box seat and and was driving. The member of the Morality Department tried to stop the carriage, but the British subject became very angry and took the cabman's whip and applied it to the cor policeman.
The case came before the British Consular wa Court and the defendant was ordered to pay a fine and costs.
You-bashi Blattner, the head of the Morality tre Department, represented the Alexandria Gou- vernorat in the case.

A correspondent writes: While heartily endorsing, were that feasible, the spirit which animates Miralai Hopkinson Bey in his an laudable endeavor to purge Alexandria, I cannot see how such ideals can be attained by the summary removal from the streets of demi-mondaines. Force is the last measure m to resort to for wiping out immorality ba because it restrains the evil-doer, not by pe the persuasion of a righteous conscience, but by fear. Where police measures are called for is in the prohibition of the entry into Egypt of these "undesirables" who have now fr to be dealt with so summarily. But the moral th salvation of Alexandria depends upon neither bu police nor the arrest of demi-mondaines- often the innocent offspring of the vices of society. No. If salvation is to come, it is in the form of reasonable, wholesome, health- giving recreation and diversion which it is in the power of the philanthropist, not the po- liceman, to give to his fellows, and which will take the place of those various forms of public entertainment which work for the moral degradation of Alexandria.

The low ebb of morality in this and other centers of Egyptian life is due to many houses, but I do not think that one of those causes is the inclination on the part of the people to be immoral. Far from it. I believe that the majority would welcome a change for the better. Circumstances, howevers, intervene. First of all, the commercial element, uncontrolled by any aristocracy, is the most militant factor against the change. This element creates selfishness, and so any effort that may be made or even suggested is nipped in the bud. Moreover, the material benefit which is the ultimate object of commercialism, completely submerges all fine ideals and aspirations. and overthrows any e barriers of good society that may have previously existed. Where, therefore, materialism is the final object, and where every talent, every virtue, every noble sentiment is sacrificed to that end, there is no outcome except that the sad spectacle of which we have to watch lto-day.

The spoiled palate cannot appreciate the pleasures of a refined and intellectual society; dit can only look to vicious joys in which to re gratify its materialistic passions. There is nothing to raise the low intellectual and moral standard of the mass of the population; nothing to combat the ill-effects of materialism, and to show that life has other objects than the acquisition of wealth. Until this lack is provided, until efforts are put forth to attract interest in of a more exalted sphere of intellect and its synonym-morality-the evil which Miralai, Hopkinson Bey seeks to purge will remain. The salvation must come from within.

div.head: THE MOTOR HOOTER.
div.p: In order to preserve the security of the the public, the Alexandria Municipality, at the instance of the police, are now occupied in the drawing up of some by laws respecting the employment of hooters on bicycles and motor cars. It has now become the fashion for the smallest bicycle to mount the biggest hooter, and every time one crosses the road a cold shiver is sent down one's back by hearing an unearthly yell from what one supposes to be a motor car. In consigning one's soul to Providence one finds that it is nothing but an innocent bicycle. But there is a reverse to the medal. It may be that by habit one thinks that it is this innocent bicyole whereas on the ad, other hand it is really a forty-horse-power Panhard that is bearing down upon one at a mere rate of fifty kilometres per hour. For these reasons the Alexandria City Police and the al Municipality think that it is necessary to make regulations by which the public may distinguish motors from bicycles by hearing the alarm signal.

div.head: THE 3RD COLDSTREAMS.
UNFAIR TREATMENT.
div.p: It is difficult to understand the policy of the Government in regard to the condemned battalions, says the 'Army and Navy Gazette." If the 3rd Batn. of the Coldstream Guards is considered a proper subject for Mr. Haldane's surgery, it may be asked why it is to leave for Egypt in September 1 Anyone would say that the very fact of its going upon this important foreign service was proof enough that it holds its right place in our military organization. But this is not the view of the authorities, and therefore the battalion is first to go to Egypt and then to be disbanded. To make matters worse for the married officers, non-com- missioned officers, and men, they are to bear the cost of the move, just as if the battalion was to be retained. Upon this subject Sir Samuel Scott was anxious to elicit some information in the House of Commons on Monday but could gain no information. No decision had been arrived at to treat this battalion, in respect of the expense of the move, differently from o'her infantry battalions. The truth is that to disband existing formations is not so easy as Mr. Haldane would wish. Effect the operation as carefully as he may, hardships are ir flicted upon individuals, and complications are inevitably the result. Everyone knows that foreign service impores initial burdens upon officers and Men, and those who are subjected to all the disappointments that, attend the disbanding of their battalions, with transfer to other units, or perhaps to half-pay, naturally do not look with favour upon a tour of service in Egypt as a preliminary, with its attendant outlay and difficulties. They have gained no satisfaction) from Mr. Haldane, who has practically said that the Government is unwilling to contri- bute to their exceptional expenditure. More generous treatment would have done greater credit to the Minister of War.

div.head: EGYPTIAN AND SUDAN BATTLEFIELDS.
div.p: The battlefields of Egypt and the Sadan are to be visited shortly by a party of travellers under the guidance of Mr. Frederick Villiers, the well-known war artist, correspondent, and traveller. The party will arrive in Lower Egypt for the Cairo season. The itinerary of the tour is to leave England early in August by the Canadian Pacific route, arriving in Manchuria early in September; return via Korea and Japan, leaving Japan for China in December, thence via the Straits Settlement to Aden and Port Sudan, where the battlefields of the East ern Sudan will be visited; then leave for Upper Egypt, arriving in Cairo toward the end o of January.

div.head: THE AMERICAN MISSION.
div.p: We have received a little pamphlet, entitled "Why are American missionaries losing ground in Egypt?" It is written in strange English and as it bears neither the names of author or publisher, it is needless to give any extracts from such an anonymous attack on a most excellent body of devoted men and women who have done yeoman service for years past in the cause of Egyptian civilisation.

div.head: NEW DREDGER FOR ALEXANDRIA
div.p: Messrs. William Simons and Company Limited, of Renfrew, lately launched, complete and ready for work, a powerful twin screw stern wheel 1,000 ton hopper dredger, which they have constructed to order of the Egyptian Government for the improvement of the Por of Alexandria The bucket ladder, which is the builders' latest girder type, is designed for dredging to a depth of 40 f. below water level. Owing to the varied nature of the material to be dredged at Alexandria two sets of buckets are provided, one set of large cubic capacity for raising free material, and one set of small buckets of exceptional strength and special design for rock dredging. The dredger is propelled at a speed of 8 knots with two sets of compound surface condensing engines, steam being supplied at 120 lbs. pressure by tv steel multitubular boilers. Suitable clatch are provided for engaging to and from, the propelling and dredging machinery. Each set of engines is arranged to drive the buckets at two speeds.

Either set of engines is available for driving the dredging gear, and, irrespective of whether the material is of a hard or soft nature, constant piston speed is always maintained. Steam hoist gear fitted with the builder friction arrangement is provided for controlling the bucket ladder. The hopper doors are closed by steam appliances, and powerful winches arranged at the bow and stern for maneuvering and regulating the out of the dredger. A donkey boiler is fitted in the stokehold supplying steam to the auxiliaries and an electric light installation, when the boilers are at rest.

div.head: OSTRICH FEATHER SALES
div.p: These sales were held in London from July 30th to the 2nd inst. and there was a good demand throughout. All good quality feathers met with good competition and were about 10 percent higher, but common feathers, which in recent sales have realised extreme prices, declined 10 percent. Egyptian feathers met a good demand, 139 cased being disposed of.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Major General Sir Reginald Wingate, D.8.0., R.A., has had the honour of being received by the King at Buckingham Palace on his return to England on leave from his command of the Egyptian Army.

Nothing official is known at the French Agency in Cairo in regard to the reported transfer of M. de la Boalinière, the French Diplomatic Agent, to Athens. The news of M. de la Boulinière's probable departure has been received with feelings of the greatest regret in Cairo, where the French Minister has won the sympathies of all with whom he has come into contact.

Sir Percy Girouard, R E., who built the Sudan Railway for Lord Kitchener, and organised the armoured trains and railway system during the South African war, has been appointed Assistant Quartermaster General in the Western Command at Aldershot.

Hopkinson Bey, Commandant of the Alex- andria City Police, has been confined to bed for the last four days with a slight indisposition. The Commandant intends to leave for Syria on the 28th inst. for a month's shooting.
Kaimakam Cobbe Bey, Sub-Commandant of Police, is expected to arrive at Alexandria on the 25th inst., and he will act as Commandant during Hopkinson Bey's abs.ca.
Dr. Goodman, Sanitary Inspector, has returned to Cairo from his inspection of Upper Egypt.
Dr. Morrison is leaving Egypt today by the Austrian Lloyd's steamer from Alexandria in two and a half months' holiday, which he will spend in Scotland. Dr. Nauphal will act as locum tenens.
Lieut. J. W. Willock, 2nd Battalion Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, has been granted an extension of his leave for four months, on the recommendation of a medical board.

The following visitors are staying at the Beau-Rivage Hotel, R-mleh: Mr. and Mrs. F. Peake, the Misses Peake, Mr. and Mrs. Boy-chelier Bey, Miss Boychelier, the Misses Gas- tar, Rev. R. Ryed, Mr. and Mrs. G. F. Baladi, Mr. C. Tedeschi, Mr. and Mrs. H. Davis, Mr. and Mrs. R. Springer and family, Mr. and Mrs. Yoanovitch and family, Mr. Hafer Hassan Bey, Mr. and Mrs. Sh. Bey Macarius and family, Mr. and Mrs. Th. B. Sanders, Mr. and Mr. Georges Brahamsha and family, Miss E. Brahamsha, Mr. and Mrs. B. Heffie, Dr. W. Zechlin, Mr. A. Ghikas, Mr. and Mrs. Watson, Mrs. A. Spence, Mr. and Mme P. 8. P. Bou- boulas, Mr. L. Loewenstein, Miss Hewat, Miss Mills, Mr. and Mrs Gabriel Bey Haddad and family, Mr. and Miss Figari, Mr. H. Rolo, Mr. A. List.

div.head: RUSSIAN REVOLUTION.
A FEMALE ANARCHIST.
GIRL THROWS BOMBS AT GENERALS
div.p: ODE SA, August 10.
The daughter of General Prir'z attempted to throw a bomb at Generals Ksulbars and Karangozok. The bomb fell and exploded without taking effect. The young girl committed suicide. (Tavas)
ST. PETERSBURG, August 10,
Large stores of arms and bombs, together with proclamations, have been seized here and in Moscow. Numbers of arrests continue to be made. (Router)

div.head: RUSSIAN MINISTRY.
div.p: ST. PETERSBURG, August 10.

Prince Vassiltohikow has been appointed Minister of Agriculture, M. Filossoffoff, Minister of Commerce, and M. Izvolsky, brother of the Foreign Minister, Procurator of the Holy Synod. All are bureaucrats. (Reuter)

div.head: U. S. A. AND JAPAN
THE SEAL POACHING INCIDENT.
div.p: NEW YORK, August 10.

Professor Elliott, the sealing authority, declares that the A'eutian raiding schooners are owned in America or Canada, but registered in Japan in order to evade responsibility. Their captains and officers are Englishmen or Americans. (Reute)
WASHINGTON, August 10.

As soon as the maneuvers of the Atlantic fleet have been completed, Rear Admiral Brownson will take some of the best armoured cruisers direct to an Asiatic station, paying no duty calls en route. It is presumed that this action is owing to the recent seal poaching in the Bering Sea by Japanese vessels. (P.)

div.head: THE SULTAN ILL.
div.p: CONSTANTINOPLE, August 10.
There, are renewed, well-accredited reports that the Sultan is ill.
SILVER BULLION FOR AMERICA.
WASHINGTON, August 10.

The Treasury will resume the purchase of silver bullion for subsidiary coinage from 15th instant. A hundred thousand ounces will be required weekly. It is understood that the Treasury has obtained the control of consider- able amounts for future delivery with a view to avoid disturbing the market. (Router)

div.head: GREEKS EXPELLED FROM ROUMANIA.
div.p: BUKAREST, August 10.
The expulsion of 57 well-to-do Greeks has been decided upon. More expulsions are impending.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: In the House of Commons, the other night, Mr. Haldane, in reply to a question on the subject, said that the permanent reinforcements made in the British army in Egypt consisted of a regiment of cavalry and fon companies of a line battalion stationed in Egypt and recalled from Crete. Mr. Haldane d further said that the Egyptian contribution to the maintenance of the Army of Occupation was £ 00,000 per annum, which represented approximately the extra cost of the force in Egyp', before the recent increase, over its cost at home, which would be about £275,000. The future strength of the British garrison would er be about 5,700, and the future contribution was under consideration.
A strong draft of Royal Horse Artillery and Royal Garrison Artillery gunners will leave England for Egypt on the 1st September to join "U" Battery R.H.A. and No. 2 Company R.G.A, at Cairo.

As soon as the exigencies of the service will permit, the 1st Battalion Lancashire Fusiliers will return from Cairo to Malta. The 4th Battalion of the Fusiliers at Tipperary is under orders for reduction.

Approaching changes in the 21st Lancers will promote Captain Protheroc-Smith-be was recently appointed to the command of the squadron of Mounted Military Police in Egypt to the rank of major. Colonel J. Fowle, who is so well known in Egypt, will vacate the e command of the 21st on the 6th September, and will be succeeded Major W.W. Cordeaux r whilst M-jor P. A. Kenns, V.C., the hero of Omdurman, will become senior major, and will discharge the duties of second in command.
Captain L. A. E. Price-Davies, V.C., D.S.O, King's Royal Rifle Corps, has been appointed to the adjutancy of the 5'h Mounted Infantry in the Transvaal, and will embark at an early date.
The proposed moves of Royal Field Artillery between South Africa, India, and home stations will remain in abeyance for the present, pending further consideration.

Several commanding officers have reported to the War Office that the short rifle is injurious to the ammunition bandolier. It seems that the spring screw of the sight aperture, and also the sight itself, cuts or tears the staff of the bandolier. Removing the square corners may remedy this defect.

It is intimated that there is no intention of reviving the abolished Depot Mountain Batte- ry, formerly stationed at Newport, Monmouthshire. The drafts for the mountain batteries in India will be prepared by the garrison companies at home, and sent to India, where they will receive the special training requisite for mountain gunners and drivers. The mounts n batteries in India now number eight- No. 1 and 9 at Quetts, Bombay; Nos. 2 and 7 at Umballa, Nos 5,/6, and 8 at Rawa' Pindi. 5./6.

The question of the lance is again receiving the attention it merits. It is stated that several distinguished cavalry officers have made strong representations to the War Office on the subject of re-arming the cavalry regiments with the lance as of old. At present it is largely carried for ceremonial purposes at home. The strongest point in its favour is its advantage in warfare against uncivilised troops, and its effectiveness in pursuit of a broken enemy. At home the lance was practically thrown aside as one of the so called "lessons" of the South African War.

Another of the battalions which Mr. Haldane has selected for extinction has been distin- guishing itself in rifle shooting. This time it is the 4th Battalion Royal Warwickshire Regi- ment, which, at the All-Ireland Rifle Meeting in County Kildare, during the past week carried off seven of the ten principal prizes, including the much-coveted Queen Victoria Challenge Cap, the great prize for marching and shooting in Ireland. This splendid record of Colonel H B. Lean's fine battalion is on a par with the re- markable achievements of the 3rd Coldstream Guards, which this year won most of the big team matches at Aldershot and Bisley, inclu- ding the "Daily Telegraph" and the Roberts Caps. It is somewhat unfortunate that the battalions chosen by Mr. Haldane for disband- ment appear to include the pick and flower of the infantry branch of the service.

The new peskel cap is being issued to some battalions and departmental troops. It is a smart-looking cap, and in every way superior to the hideous and detested "Brodrick," which without doubt is the most atrocious outrage ever perpetrated in the way of military tai- loring. The new cap is, of course, a bit German- looking, the "Brodrick" being its parent in a manner, but it resembles closely an undress cap worn by the officers cf Rifle regiments in the early years of the last century, and in certain militia regiments a short time prior to the Crimean War. On the whole it has been well received after the Brodrick.
The Atlantic Fleet will arrive at Gibralter about the first week of September, after having made a series of visits to the Irish and English ports.

div.head: PITH OF THE PRESS.
THE GOVERNMENT AND THE TRANSVAAL
div.p: OPINIONS ON-THE NEW CONSTITUTION

The mere fact that the decision on the constitutional issue in the Transvaal has at last been announced, that some sort of settlement has been decided upon, and that the settlement, such as it is, is to be pUt into effect without delay has been received with a general feeling of relief both in South Africa and in this country. There are many features in that element which are very far from satisfactory, and can only give rise to the gravest apprehensions as to their effect upon the political and material welfare of the colony. But, on the whole, the verdict seems to be that things might well have been worse. It would be abeer irony to interpret this attitude of acquiescence as a testimony to the statesmanship of the Government. On the contrary, it only throws into stronger relief the unwisdom of the line of action pursued during the last six months, of the policy of inter- ference and menace from which any avenue of escape is welcome, however great the risks that may attend. ("Times.")
"Might have been Worse."

No better criterion of the estimation in which the present Administration is held by Impe- rialists and men of business in all quarters of the Empire could be desired than is furnished by the sigh of relief with which the Ministerial proposals with regard to the Transvaal Constitution have been received. "It might have been worse," is the phase which summarises public opinion in the Colonies and in the City. The provisional solution of a great Colonial problem is not good, it is bad, but it fallen short of being as bad as it might be. What a comment upon the wisdom and patriotism of the Crown! Nobody expected of them that they would treat as paramount the interest and well-being of the Empire as a whole. Many feared that they would sacrifice such interests to the demands of a clamorous and ignorant section in the House of Commons. And the fact that they did not go quite so far as that is hailed by lovers of their country as a wel- come concession. ("Telegraph.")
The Cabinet Intimidated.

When we are given the text of the Letters Patent it will be seen, perhaps, from certain other indications, that the Government are by no means happy in their mind about the plunge which they have taken. It is also obvious that the scheme explained by Lord Elgin and Mr. Winston Churchill is a com- promise between conflicting programmes. The patches are plain in the texture. Between the Byles type of pro-Boers and the moderate Liberals it was necessary to work out a sort of modus vivendi, and in the not very simple task of extorting concessions from the Little Eng- landers, they were, we may reasonably suspect, assisted by jadicions quotations from the West Ridgeway Report. The text of that mysterious document they dare not publish for reasons quite easy to understand,
Liberals Satisfied.

We do not agree with those proposals at every point. We gave yesterday our reasons for regretting that the Government had adopted the "voters basis" in place of the "population basis" in the distribution of seats. At the same time, we have long been aware that that departure had been determined on, and it remained to be seen how, this being granted, the Government would deal with the situation. On the whole, we do not think that they could easily have done better. Indeed, their proposals cover so nearly the points which we have repeatedly urged that we should be both un- grateful and inconsistent if we did not give them hearty support. ("Tribune.")
Opinion at the Cape.

Mr. Charobill's outline of a Constitution will be read with relief in South Africa. A compromise was inevitable, but the Britishers have been safeguarded perhaps as well as possible in the circumstances. The distribution of seats is fairer than might have been expected. (Cape Times.")
What Bloemfontein Thinks.

The people of this Colony have loyally redeemed their undertaking at Vereeniging. Any postponement of their claim after the Traus- vaal's is unnecessary, if it does not amount to a direct breach of faith. The Orange River Colony is at least as fit to be trusted as the capitalist-governed Rand. We refrain, however, from hard words until we know exactly what the Imperial Government means. ('Bloemfontein Friend.")
Victory for Common-sense.
The Imperial decision is a victory for com- mon-sense. We hope the Imperial Government will leave well alone. ("Bloemfontein Post.")
The Question of Chinese Labour,

"It is by no means certain that the graduated modification of authoritative govern- ment advocated by the Conservatives would do more for the Anglicization of the Colony than the generosity of the Liberals. But the Liberal project will be all the more fiercely attacked because it runs counter to strong financial interests by suppressing Asiatic labour in the mines. The Liberal Government has taken an initiative which will have considerable effect upon Great Britain's own policy, to say nothing of the wider questions it touches in South Africa." (M. Robert de Caix in the "Debate.")

div.head: EGYPTIAN RECORDS.
div.p: The first of the University of Chicago's ancient record series is nearly complete, the third volume of "Ancient Records of Egypt" having come from the University press. The fourth and last of this series will follow soon, and then will appear two other sets of books, one covering the old records of Assyria and Babylonia and the other those of Palestine. J Phoenecia and Syria. All were prepared under the general supervision of the late William O Rainey Harper, who is the author of the Palestine, Phoaicia, Syria series.

James Henry Breasted, professor of Egypto- logy and Oriental history at the University of Chicago, is the author of the "Ancient Records of Egypt. These books when complete will contain translations of all the sources of M ancient Egyptian history, and will be the only books of their kind. Judeed, never before has the attempt been made to put all the historical records into a modern language. The work required years of research abroad, Professor Breasted making his own translations from the original documents wherever possible.

The translations have been made as literal as possible so that the original meaning of the documents would not suffer in the change to English. The author has what he terms a "righteous horror" of the romancing of translators who allow their fancies to enter so largely into their work that the original meaning is lost, although the romancer may have produced some very delightful tales. He has sacrificed "romance" in the interests of exactness.

In selecting historical documents Professor Breasted has excluded purely religions, literary, 1 scientific, mathematical and medical compositions. Business documents have also been extended, excepting in reference to the Old Kingdom, where the scarcity of material made it necessary to translate these. The four volumes include translations of all the written documents from which the historical knowledge of the Egyptian peoples as a nation to the ! occupation of the country by the Persians in 525 B. C. is drawn.
Preceding the translation of each document, the author has placed an explanatory note. Numerous foot notes add to the clearness of the work.
As an example of the books' contente, in volume III Professor Breasted writes concerning the Temple of Karnak:

"The northern half of the great hypostyle hall', including the nave, with both its rows of columns and also the first row south of the Dave, are the work of Seti 1. The pylon in front of the hall was at least begun under Rameses I. Seti's portion of the hall contains architrave inscriptions and dedications, re- cording the building as his work, though it was finished under his son, Rameses II. Its name was Temple-of the Son of Seti Meremon- in-the House-of-Amon."
Then follows the translation of the particular document under consideration:

"Seti I; he made (it) as a monument for his father, Amon-Re, Lord of Thebes; making for him a great and splendid temple of fine sandstone... Utterance of Amon-Re, king of gods: '0, my son, of my body, my beloved, lord of the Two Lands, Menmare (3eti 1), Begotten of Re. Thou hast made festive my house a (new); how exalted, how greatly extended are the august precincts, which existed before the kings of Upper and Lower Egypt. No god put into their hearts to make (the like of that which thou hast made)." Most persons find Egypt a source of fascinating study and Breasted's works will prove a delight to them. The books are primarily for the student and Egyptologist.

div.head: AERONAUT AND LUNATICS.
div.p: From Rome is reported an extraordinary incident, of which the moral seems to be that besides the general care which all should exercise for avoiding such institutions, the aeronaut in the air should be especially careful to steer clear of a lunatic asylum. A balloon floating over the Janiculum the other day passed close to the local asylum, with the guide rope so near the ground that inmates made a general j yous and successful rash for it. Having secured it, they held on with a gleeful tenacity that would have ensured triumph in a tag-of war, and it required the full strength of the asylum staff, supplemented by a few policemen, to free the balloon before it had been brought to wreck among the chimney stacks.

div.head: EGYPT'S IRON TRADE IN 1905.
SOME INTERESTING STATISTICS.
div.p: The annual Statistical Report presented to the members of the British Iron Trade Association on the home and foreign iron and allied industries for the year 1905 gives some interesting particulars of the iron trade of Egypt.

Egypt (the report says) has no native iron industry, but its consumption of imported iron and steel has steadily increased for a number of years past. Through the courtesy of Chitty Bey, the Director of Customs, the statistics of imports for 1905 have been forwarded for the purposes of this Report, as issued by that Department, together with records of the recent statistical progress of this country in its commercial aspects generally.
The imports of iron and steel are classified under the heads that follow, the units being given as well as the value for the year 1905 where they are available:
Practically the whole of this quantity was received into the port of Alexandria.
The tonnage of wrought iron and steel im- ported into Egypt in 1903 was 72,543 tons, a figure which compares with 62,013 tons in the previous year, and with 48,495 tons in 1901.
The value of the imports of wrought iron and steel into Egypt increased from L.E. 251,962 in 1884 to L.E. 423,949 in 1903.

The value of the imports of iron casting rose from LE. 83,687 in 1898 to LE. 170.303 in in 1903; that of hardware and ironmongery, etc., from L.B. 169,218 in the former year to LE. 372,233 in 1903; and that of tin-plates and sheets within the same interval from LE 27,819 to L.E. 76,226.

LONDON & PARIS EXCHANGE LIMITED, GENERAL BANKERS. BASILDON HOUSE, BANK, LONDON, E.C.
Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
NOTES ET CRITIQUES.
Le Caire, 10 Août.

A Londres, le Consolidé anglais a encore haussé hier de 1/4 à 88 1/2. L'Unifiée a gagné également 1/4 à 104 5/8. La National Bank a avancé d'antant à 25 3/4. L'Agricole a pro gressé de 1/8 à 9 3/4. Ls Daira est restés invariée à 16 7/8, de même que la Delts Light à 11 1/2..
A Paris, l'action Crédit Foncier Egyptien a clôturé en reprise de 1 franc à 759. La Banque d'Athènes & rattrapé, à 149, les 3 francs qu'elle avait perdus la veille.

Sur notre marché des valeurs, la séance de ce matin a été aussi intéressante, sinon aussi active, que celle d'hier. Au début, il s'est pro- dait une sorte d'emballement, qui n'a pas tardé à se calmer sous l'effet des réalisations. Anssi bien la clôture a été quelque peu moins ferme, mais avec des cours relativement soutenus sur toute la ligne.

Suivant toutes les apparence, la reprise se maintiendra plas ou moins jasque vers la fin du mois, sauf événements de nature à re- mettre les fonds d'Etat rasses sur la voie d'une baisse inquiétante pour les places dirigeantes d'Occident.

A l'ouverture, la National Bank a été portée à 26 pour clôturer à 25 15/16-26. L'Agricole a avancé à 9 13/16-7/8 pour revenir à 9 3/4. Ls Cassa di Sconto s'est raffermie à 225 l'action ancienne et. 214 la nouvelle. Le Comptoir Financier a réactionné à 6 5/8 l'action ancienne et 6 3/8-7/16 la nouvelle.

L'action Crédit Foncier a été traitée à 758; l'obligation à lots ancienne a encore gagné 2 tranos à 338. La Delta Light a été demandée à 11 5/8. Le Wardan Estate a atteint 7 et la Nile Land 13 1/4. L'Enterprise and Development a faibli à 11 15/16. La part de fondateur Agricole da Nil a progressé de 1/8 à 7 1/8. L'Union Foncière s'est négociée à 6. 3/16-1/4. L'action Butreprises Immobilières et Travaux s'est maintenue à 41/4; la part de fondateur à 69.
La Brasserie des Pyramides est remontée à | 130. Les Héliopolis ont été négociés entre 297 et 298; la part de fondateur à 9.

Dans le groupe des valeurs hôtelières, les Nungovich ont été poussés à 14 7/8. L38 Egyptian ont faibli à 6 1/16-1/8. Ba bonne te- nue, les Upper Erypt ont clôturé à 5-5 1/16. Parmi les petite; valeurs, les Delta Land, toujours mouvemen'és, ont fait 3 21/32 pour olôturer plas faib'es à 3 1/2-9/16. Les Estates se sont raffermis à 1 7/8-15/16; la part de fondateur à 11. Les Oasis ont fléchi à 1 1/16 et les Cotton Mills à 5 sb. 9.

Saivant des renseignements que nous rece vons de Londres, l'assemb'ée générale ordinaire de l'Egyptian Delta Land and Investment Co.. convoquée pour jeudi prochain, promet d'être fort intéressante. Das questions nombreuses seront posées par divers groupes d'actionnaires au sujet de la situation réelle de la Société, de son programme fatar, des bénéfices réalisés dans le semestre courant depuis le 31 Mars dernier, etc.

On affirme, d'autre part, que le Chairman est préparé à donner les explications les plas satisfaisantes. Il parait acquis que les profits résultant de la vente des terrains de Maad, sur la ligne d' Hélonan, s'élèvent à près de £60,000.
La date précise da paiement du coupon in- térimaire de P. B. 20 sur les actions ancienne de la Cassa di Sconto e di Risparmio n'est pas encore officiellement fixée.
Ce coupon ne sera pas payé le 15 du courant, comme on l'avait tout d'abord annoncé, mais bien dans is seconds quinzaine du mois, ou su plus tard dans les premiers jours de septembre.

Si nos infirmations sont exactes, le mouve ment de hausse qui s'est récemment dessiné sur les actions de la Wardan Estate Co. doit être attribué à l'excellente marche actuelle des affaires de cette Société.

L'établissement d'un canal à travers le do maine de la Compagnie a pour effet de di- minuer considérablement les frais d'irrigation, par suite de la suppression du travail des pompes. Les terrains se prêtent aujourd'hui avantageusement à la culture, et, sur certains points, le feddan trouverait aisément preneur AL. E. 100.
Carnet de l'actionnaire.

L'Administration des Chemins de fer de l'Etat a l'honneur d'informer le public qu'à l'instar de l'année dernière elle a reccueilli dans un livret spécial le Tarif qui sera mis en vigueur durant la prochaine saison cotonnière 1906-907 pour le transport du coton (égrené et, pressé hydrauliquement ou à la vapeur, et non égrené) ainsi que des graines de coton.

En vae d'augmenter les facilités réaliséas par ce Tarif, une légère modification est introdoite au tarif du coton non égrené taxé par sac. En effet, pendant la saison dernière la taxe par sac était établie sur la base de 225 kg. mais le poids des sacs n'ayant pas excédé 200 kg. ainsi qu'il a été constaté, c'est sur ce poids que la taxe a été basée dans le présent Tarif.

A cet avantage pour les négociants qui expédient leurs cotons non égrenés par sac se joint celai d'être dispensés de présenter des états des poids détaillés de leurs expéditions et ils bénéficieront d'an délai de grâce de 96 heures au lieu de 48.

Le livret dont il est question va être inces samment envoyé à tous les négociants de coton connus ainsi qu'aux Gires et pourra être en- voyé gratis à tous ceux qui en feront la demande à Mr. le Directeur du Service des Marohandises an Caire.
Administration des Chemins de Fer de l'Etat Egyptien
AVIS

L'Administration a l'honneur de porter à la connaissance du Public qu'elle recevra jns- qu'au Lundi 21 Septembre prochain à midi des Joffres pour la fourniture d'articles sanitaires tela que cuvettes, urinoirs, sièges, tayauterie, etc., selon le cahier des charges dont on peut t,obtenir copie contre paiement de 200 (deux cents millièmes) aux services des Magasins à Boulac (Caire) et à Gabbary (Alexandrie). e. Offre pour "Articles Sanitaires,"
L'Administration ne s'engage pas à accepter mi l'offre la plus basse, ni à donner suite aux sou- as missions présentées; elle se réserve le droit de ar diviser la commande.
Le Caire, le 9 Août 1906.

div.head: REVUE COMMERCIALE
div.p: Cotons.

Le bon sens nons commandait de ne pas oroire à la possibilité de la formation d'un syndicat sur août, et de la façon dont les choses se sont passées sur le marché dans la première partie de la semaine, en tant que cela con- perne la vieille récolte, nous semblions avoir raison; mais après les manoeuvres auxquelles nous assistons depuis hier et après le retrait des filières par certaines personnes, le doute n'est plus permis. Nous le regrettons sincère- ment tant pour le fait lui-même qu'à cause des intéressés, car c'est une gaffe de ples à ajouter à celles qui ont déjà été com- mises cette année; mais il a fallu que des non-professionnels se trouvassent engagés jus- qu'au cou pour arriver à une pareille com- binaison. Du reste, ce serait là la seule ex- case qu'ils pourraient faire valoir pour jus- tifier leur opération entreprise, certainement non de propos délibéré, mais bien parce qu'ils ont eu la main forcée et dans un bat de défense de leurs intérêts.-Et puis, en fin de compte, ils sont assez riches pour se payer os caprice, si caprice il y a eu, en cas où le coup, comme cela est probable, viendrait à rater. Ceci dit, passons à la revue du marché.

Au lieu de la fermeté à laquelle d'aucuns s'attendaient, c'est le calme et la faiblesse qui ont régné pendant la matinée de samedi, et comme résultat c'est une baisse de 1/8 que nous avons eu à enregistrer.

Lundi ayant été jour férié, la reprise des affaires n'a en lien que mardi et cette seconde éance a été marquée par un recul ultérieur de 1/3; mais, ce qui a é'é an comble et en même temps une véritable surprise, c'est la dégringolade de 19/32 qui s'est produite le lendemain et qui n'a en d'autre raison que l'offre de quelques milliers de cantars de flot- tant et la crainte d'une filière, plus grosse qu'on ne le disait, pour le jour suivant.

Au fond, cette tenue du marché était ridi- cale et indiquait de l'hésitation outrée de la part du groupe haossier; seulement, et fort heureusement pour lai, elle n'a pas duré, les circonstances étant venues à son secours. Ea effet, hier, aussitôt la filière émise, et elle n'a été que de cantars 18750, une demande a surgi tout à coup pour l'acût et tout naturel- lement les intéressés ont saisi la balle au bond pour réagir. L'août a été poussé presque d'un seal trait à 20 1/4, mais la constatation faite que tous ceux qui avaient aidé à chauffer le marché ne visaient qu'à se débarrasser de ce qu'ils avaient en contrats vieille récolte calma an peu l'ardeur du syndicat et nous valut une réaction à 19 7/8. Toutefois la clôture eut liea à 20 tallaris.
Ce matin, les baissier: s'étant terus tran- gailles, il a été facile aux intéressés à la hausse de soutenir les cours et comme finale de la semaine, c'est à 20 3/32 que l'Août s'est inscrit.

Comme résumé, c'est une nouvelle perte de 11/32 depuis vendredi dernier que l'Août subit, mais comme tendance, bien malin serait celui qui saurait l'indiquer. Da reste, les accapareurs de l'Août eux-mêmes ne savent pas ce qu'ils feront par la suite et, pour le moment, ils se contentent à mauvais jen de faire boane mire, en protestant contre les velléités d'égorgement qu'on leur prête et en disant qu'au fond ils De foot qu'une affaire commerciale, etc., etc. Certes, cela ne les empêchera pas de profiter da moindre découvert qui pourrait se pré- senter et la vérité est que si aujourd'hui ile Teçoivent, c'est qu'il ne peuvent pas faire autrement. Quant à la liquidation finale, cela les regarde, mais, ce qui est incontestable, c'est que e temps leur manquera pour tout écouler avant que le nouvean coton ne vienne 138 entraver d'une façon sérieuse. Dans tous les cas, nous ne croyons pas qu'il y aura des ruines comme prix, car sur la base de 19 1/2 pour fully good fair, la filature anglaise, qui a des besoins pressants, a montré quelques dispositions aux achats. Elle n'avalera cer- tainement pas toute la quantité que le Byndicat pourra lui offrir, mais quand même et malgré la question de la qualité, une partie de re coton pourra trouver son placement auprès de la filature dans des conditions relati- vement raisonnables. Dans notre précédente revue, nous nous sommes suffisamment étendas sur cette affaire et nous ne voulons pas fatiguer le lecteur par des redites. Nous nous arrêtons donc pour aujourd'hui en résumant l'opinion générale qui prévaut à ce sujet en disant que quelles que soient les conditions dans lesquelles elle se terminers, elle sera tou jours une opération à perte.

La tenue de la nouvelle récolte a encore une fois é'é d'une fermeté extraordinaire; ni la baisse de l'Américain, ni l'abstention du commerce n'ont pu arrêter les haussiers et en définitive c'est à 17 1/2 que clôture le Novembre, soit avec an bénéfice de 1/16 sur Vendredi passé. C'est beau si l'on veut et poar sûr les rachats da découvert ont aidé à ce soutien, mais il semble que les haussiers négligent un pen trop ce qui se passe autour pour ne s'attrapper qu'à ce seul point. Contrairement à ce que nous pensions, il y a ea quelques résiliations de la part de la filature et plus d'an consommateur a déjà pris ses dispositions pour se mettre à l'américain. Pour le moment il ne s'agit que de cas isolés, mais la chose pourrait bien finir par s'étendre parmi les filateurs des numéros courants, si l'énorme écart actuel entre américain et égyptien se maintenait. La position locale ne suffit pas pour justifier la continuation du mouvement et il faut forcément tenir compte de la consommation: on a marché trop tôt et avec la baisse de l'américain les choses changent un peu d'aspect, car au bout du compte tout le monde ne file pas da fin et une partie de la consommation pent toujours être modifiée quand le filateur trouve son avantage à employer d'autres sortes et qu'il a le temps de s'y préparer. Nous pourrions bien avoir quelque surprise désagréable de ce côté-là.

Le résumé de Juillet de la Produce Association que nous reproduisons plus loin est très favorable à la récolte, mais quoique la plante soit dans de meilleures conditions que l'année dernière pour résister aux brouillards et aux intempéries qui pourraient survenir par la suite, il ne faut pas se fier d'une façon absolue aux belles apparences habituelles au mois de Jaillet. Oa a déjà signalé de Zagazig l'apparition d'un brouillard mardi de nier, mais il parait qu'il n'a été que de courte durée et n'a fait aucun mal. Dans tous les cas, nous ajoute- rons que si la température actuelle persiste, les chances sont pour une bonne réussite de la récolte.
Le marché du disponible a été absolument ca'me et c'est toujours la pénurie du choix qui entrave les affaires.

Quant aux prix, faute de pouvoir les con- stater d'une façon effective, c'est en se basant sur les cours des contrats qu'ils ont été établis dans la cote officielle de ce matin, d'cù la erbaisse de 3/8 sar les Mit Affifi.

Les Joannovich ont été par contre main etenus à leur niveau, précédent tandis que les provenances Haute Egypte ont été supprimées ( par suite de leur épuisement presque complet Les exportations de la semaine ont été une véritable déception avec leur total de 4,400. balles, contre 14,400 pour la même période en 1905, mais il convient de faire remarquer que cette semaine il n'y a pas eu de départ la pour Marseille et qu'il y a eu du retard dar su certains embarquements pour Liverpool. Cela & viendra la semaine prochaine; toutef is, il ne P faudrait pas se faire trop d'illusions sur ce g point, car même avec des expéditions un peu plus importantes pour le restant d'août, la campagne parait destinée à finir avec un arriéré de près de 200,000 cantars.
Liverpool a été tavorable et régulier commer demande pour les égyptiens disponibles et i comme moyenne les ventes journalières se sont à élevées à 500 bales.

Du côté des prix, cependant, les choses n'ont pes marché comme on aurait voulu, la cote de de jour nous montrant une baisse de 1/16 pour le spot qui est à 10 1/4, de 8/64 pour l'août tombé à 9 58/64 et de 10/64 pour le novembre qui recule à 8 51/64.

Pour les américains il y a eu aussi un peu plus d'activité, mais les cours, pour leur part, ont été encore plus maltraités que cenx de l'Egyptien et cela à cause de la baisse de New- York. En fait, le spot a reculé de 30 points à la cote de 5.68, le juillet-août de 29 points à 5.43 et l'octobre novembre de 25 points à 5.33.

L'effet du dernier rapport du bureau d'agri- culture a été de faire changer de position à Price et consorts qui seraient aujourd'hui à la baisse. Du reste, les nouvelles de la récolte sont satisfaisantes et cela peut justifier la volte face. Seulement, on semble aller trop vite dans la voie de la baisse et plus d'une personne sé- rieuse pense que le coton américain, à ce ni- vean, mérite un peu plus d'attention. L'état de l'industrie cotonnière est toujours prospère, et ceux qui sont à la tête du mouvement actuel peuvent bien sous peu tourner casaque epx- mêmes. Ils trouveront toujours un bon prétexte pour modifier leur attitude.
Graines de Coton
Le marché da disponible n'existant plus de fait, nous n'avons pour aujourd'hui à nous Occuper que des contrats.

Ceux ci ont été l'objet d'une bonne demande, dont la conséquence a été de faire monter Paoût à P.T. 71 1/4. Hall, qui se faisait tirer T'oreille pour acheter, a fini par payer jusqu'à £6.18/9, ce qui justifie nos cours.

La hausse en Angleterre est due à une amé lioration des tourteaux qui sont demandés. Comme exportations, la semaine a été plutôt insignifiante, mais pour le restant d'Août il y a des engagements est més à 190,000 ardebs environ. Si quelques nouvelles affaires ont en- core lieu, nous finirons presque sans stock à la fin du mois.
La nouvelle récolte a été très ferme, mais n'a suivi que lentement la hausse de l'ancienne. Dans tous les cas, les 3 mois sont à 64 3/4 et en bonne tendance.
Il nous faudrait toutefois un réveil de la demande anglaise pour les échéances éloignées Pour le moment elle a l'air de les négliger en maintenant sa cote à £65/- on £6.6/3 pour ele Novembre-Janvier.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA GENERAL PRODUCE ASSOCIATION
div.p: SECTION COTONNIÈRE

Résumé des réponses reçues en Juillet 1906: La température pendant le mois de Juillet a été très favorable à la récolte; les fortes cha- leurs ont largement profité aux cotonniers et lear ont fait regagner, presque partout, le retard précédemment signalé.
L'aspect des plantes est sain et vigoureux. La floraison est abondante, des noix se sont formées partout et semblent sassi nombreuses que l'année dernière à la même époque.

On a encore constaté la présence des vers et quelques rares apparitions de papillons, mais partout les mesures prises pour leur extirpation ont en plein suocès et la forte chaleur a été anesi d'an secours précieux.
Dans le Nord da Bébéra seul, il a eu quel- ques plaintes au sujet des dégâts causés par les vers, sans grande importance toutefois.
L'eau a été suffisante et a permis une irrigs- tion régulière dans toutes les provinces.
Les informations de la Haute-Egypte et do Fayoum sont satisfaisantes et il n'y a pas en
de vers.
Da Fayoum on dit qu'il y a toujours un peu de retard, mais qu'il est partiel.
Alexandrie, le 9 Août 1906.

BREMEN.

div.head: CHRONIQUE FINANCIERE
div.p: Alexandrie, le 10 Août 1906.

Nous avons eu cette semaine une reprise à se laquelle peu de personnes s'attendaient. Le mois d'août, en effet, correspond à la période nnuelle de calme plat, sans haut ni bas bien prononcés: le relèvement de la cote, accompa gné d'an mouvement assez intense de transsc- tions à cette époque de l'année, & done surpris m le plus grand nombre.

Cependant, à la bourse, comme ailleurs, tout th asa raison d'être. En l'occarrence, la hauese ne représente qu'une réaction. Par suite d'alarmes injustifiées on était tombé ces temps derniers à des cours très bas, correspondant presque à un dixième de perte pour les valears les plus solides. C'était d'abord l'incident de Denchawi dont on craignait les suites, pais les affaires de Russie qui semblaient se compliquer d'ane façon inextricable, enfin un malaise général inspirant de la méfiance aux capitalistes et les écartant de la corbeille.

Maintenant qu'ils ont pu s'apercevoir que A l'Angleterre avait tout prévu pour mainte nir ici le bon ordre, les égyptiens reprennent peu à peu le cours de leurs transactions; en Russie la paix semble aussi renaitre par la répres-t sion et le bruit d'une entrevue du roi Edouard avec le kaiser fiait de calmer toutes les appré- hensions. Tels sont les principaux motifs qu'on allègue pour le réveil de notre marché. Mais il y a pour l'amélioration des cours une raison bien plus simple: une baisse exagérée en face d'ane abondance croissante de espitaux. Une foule de circonstances ont d'ailleurs concoura favoriser le mouvement haussier: l'Amérique ayant momentanément cessé de drainer les capitaux européens, ceux-ci doivent naturelle- ment chercher un autre emploi ; les cotons étant en hausse, les gains réalisés se déversent en partie dans la corbeille des valears; enfin, le taux d'oscompte privé vient d'être réduit en Angleterre à 3%, tandis que le Consolidé se relève à 88 1/2. A Paris il y a également hausse de la rente et des valeurs égyptiennes. Voilà plus qu'il n'en faut pour expliquer la reprise de ces derniers jours. C'est une simple réaction. Il n'est pas vraisemblable, à cette époque de l'antée, qu'il y ait un mouvement, saivi et important à la hausse. Il faut pour cela attendre, comme toujours, la fin des vacan- ces et la rentrée des capitalistes d'Europe. Tout su plas y aura-t-il une légère accentua tion de la reprise pour certains titres encore trop dépréciés.
Sur une cinquantaine de valeurs inscrites à la cote officielle de la Bourse d'Alexandrie 28 sont en hausse, 7 seulement en baisse et 24 restent stationnaires aux cours antérieur.

Les fluctuations les plus remarquables sont: à la hausse, la National Bank qai gagne 5/8, la Ramleh Railway 5/8, les Nangovich Hotels 1 livre 1/16, la Delta Land 7/16, la Nile Land 1/2, la part de fondatear Comptoir 3 livres 1/2, et l'Union Foncière 9/32; à la baisse, les pertes sont insignifiantes.

On attribue la bausse considérable de la Delta Land au découvert d'une importante maison du Caire qui a da se couvrir au plus vite. Cette coïncidence n'aurait pas été étran- gère à la reprise générale en donnant au marché un aspect animé qu'il avait perda depuis long- temps et en faisant croire à l'entrée en scène du graud mouvement d'automne. Ainsi que nous l'avons dit dans notre dernière chronique, c'est jeudi prochain que doit avoir lieu l'as- semblée générale de la Delta Land pour examiner le bilan et approuver, s'il y a lieu, les résolutions prises à l'assemblée extraordi- naire da 19 jaillet dernier.

Pour le Comptoir Financier et Commercial nous avons donné les causes da relèvement des cours dans notre dernière chronique. En ce qui concerne l'Union Foacière, il y a une excellente opération conclue dernièrement par cette société et consistant dans la vente de 130 feddans de terrains à Dar el Bakar pour la somme de L.E. 10,000; ce qui re- présente un bénéfice de L.B. 5,450 sur le prix d'achat. Cette même société vient d'acheter ALE 45'e teddan 400 faddans de terrains qui valent en leur état actuel L.E. 60 le feddan.

La Delta Light est essentiellement ane retardataire dans les mouvements de bourse; ainsi, tandis que la plupart des valeurs, y com- pris les banques, sont en reprise marquée, elle 5 reste stationnaire à 11 9/ 6, en dépit de ses bonnes recettes.

L'Administration des chemins de fer est en train d'élaborer un tarif spécial pour le trans- port des marchandises appartemant à la société des Sucreries et Raffinerie d'Egypte, ainsi que les clauses du contrat de cession des voies ferrées a de la Compagnie. En attendant, le cours de la avaleur tombe de fr. 26 à 25.

Le conseil d'administration du Crédit Fon- acier Egyptien vient d'appeler le deuxième quart sur les actions de la société soit 125 fr. par titre, en deux versements égaux à effectuer, le premier du ler an) 6 septembre 1906 et le second du 2 au 8 janvier 1907.

Conformément à la décision prise à son Assemblés générale extraordinaire da 7 Juillet dernier, la Banque d'Athères va porter son capital de 20 à 40 millions de drachmes par la création de 200,000 actions nouvelles d'ane D valeur nominale de 100 drachmes: 100,000 de ces actions seront remises aux porteurs des 150,000 actions du Crédit Industriel de Grèce, en échange de leurs propres titres; les autres 100,000 seront offertes en souscription, jonis- sance da ler Janvier 1907, au prix de dr. 152.50 aux actionnaires actuels de la Banque d'Athè nes, dans la proportion de 1 action nouvelle pour 2 anciennes; les porteurs ont en outre le droit de souscrire, sous réserve des possibili és d'attributions, une quantité supplémentaire de titres à leur convenance.

En général, on s'attend pour la semaine prochaine à une accentuation du mouvement de hausse. Mais nous ne ore yons pas que ce mouvement doive prendre de grandes propor- tions jusqu'à la rentrée d'automne.
